1.31.23  7:18 am   here's what i don't get about the theory that "the universe is a simulation"... if our universe is a simulation, that means that there must be a universe that runs this simulation. If there isn't one, and this "simulation" just exists on its own somehow, that would mean the distinction between "real" and "simulation" would be completely arbitrary. so there's another universe that runs this one. but if that's the case, that universe would be the "real" one, and you still run into the same issues that the simulation theory is trying to solve, because how did that universe come into being? is it ALSO a simulation? what about the universe controlling that simulation? you can't just keep going on infinitely, eventually you have to come across the "original" universe. but anyway... what are your thoughts on this

1.30.23  3:16 am   hi bill, i'm starting to get into songwriting in the opposite way you did, where i'm writing songs before learning an instrument. like to write songs, i'm essentially singing the melody-lyric and tapping out a rhythm into the microphone, and writing down the lyrics so i remember them.

     this comes very easy to me, way easier than it does for you,

     like i can pretty much immediately come up with the next part of the song easily after listening / reading it through, or even just thinking about the song off-handedly, as long as i have enough mental energy

      (which hasn't been that often until recently due to my chronic illness, but that's another story entirely). it hasn't taken me much longer than like a couple hours or so to finish writing any of my full-length (like 2-3 minute) songs so far, one of them was even written in a half hour and i still really like it,

      although i haven't finished more than like 10 or 15 (i haven't counted yet), and my almost-finished songs have been at a similar pace too. as i've started. so the songwriting is going fantastic so far. anyways i'm getting off track, the problem is, i have little to no experience with any musical instrument, and know no way of coming up with chords other than entering the melody notes in a website to figure out the scale, looking up the notes & chords in that scale, and hoping for the best. do you have any tips for me to get better at using the instrument and learning how chords work naturally?

      since i know that's how you learned yours, and had pretty much the exact opposite problems as me when it came to writing & recording songs,  

     so i wondered if you had any tips for a beginner approaching music in the opposite order as you,

     as a pretty confident songwriter only now approaching the instrument hurdle as a necessary way to get things recorded. thabks
